title.narrative: Responding to the interconnected socio-environmental crisis in Chocó, Colombia

description.narrative: The objective of this project is to respond to the interconnected crisis people and planet are facing in Chocó by providing technical and legal support to AfroColombian, Indigenous and campesino organisations (ETOs), who are defending their territory, and thereby through creative legal, cultural and political advocacy actions promoting and celebrating local agency and voice of some of the most marginalised and vulnerable communities in Colombia. This project will be carried out through three lines of action: 1) working with a ruling on the restitution of territorial rights in favour of the Community Council of the Upper Atrato Peasant and Popular Organisation (COCOMOPOCA), which is ground-breaking in terms of recognizing the relationship between armed conflict and large-scale mining, and the recognition of the right to prior consultation during all the phases of mining projects; 2) the Atrato Fest, which is a way to reconnect with the river, revitalise cultural practices and fosters community ownership of the Atrato River Ruling (T-622 of 2016) through art, care and protection of the river; and 3) the defence of artisanal fishing which is not only the defence of the food sovereignty of vulnerable communities but, from a biocultural perspective, it is a way to vindicate the AfroColombian cultural identity and, also, a way to protect the marine ecosystems seriously threatened by overexploitation.
